G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction pursuant to **G.L. c. 212, § 4**, as the damages exceed $25,000 in controversy.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester County under **G.L. c. 223, § 1**, because the incident occurred in Worcester and the Defendant resides or conducts business in Worcester.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Defendant owed a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the premises and sidewalk adjacent to her property in a reasonably safe condition, including by removing or mitigating any snow or ice hazards, pursuant to Massachusetts law.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Mounsey v. Ellard is a concurring opinion discussing the abandonment of the invitee/licensee distinction and the treatment of trespassers; it does not address duties regarding snow and ice removal or maintenance of sidewalks adjacent to property. While Mounsey is generally significant for expanding occupier liability under Massachusetts law, this excerpt does not establish a specific duty to remove or mitigate snow and ice hazards on abutting sidewalks. Therefore, this citation does not directly support the specific proposition about snow and ice duties.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that “trespassers” stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential.

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Defendant owed a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the premises and sidewalk adjacent to her property in a reasonably safe condition, including by removing or mitigating any snow or ice hazards, pursuant to Massachusetts law.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The court expressly abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and holds that Massachusetts premises liability law imposes the same duty of reasonable care for hazards arising from snow and ice as for any other hazard. It states that a property owner (or person responsible for maintaining the property) must act reasonably to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition, including with respect to snow and ice on areas such as walkways and parking lots, and applies this rule retroactively. That directly supports the proposition that a defendant owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain premises and adjacent walking areas in a reasonably safe condition by addressing snow and ice hazards.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’… If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

G.L. c. 85, \u00a7 5.proposition: Pursuant to **G.L. c. 85, § 5**, property owners are responsible for maintaining sidewalks abutting their property free of dangerous snow and ice conditions.

Halley v. Hugh Nawn, Inc., 356 Mass. 28.raw_text: Halley v. Hugh Nawn, Inc., 356 Mass. 28 (1969)
Halley v. Hugh Nawn, Inc., 356 Mass. 28.proposition: Defendant’s conduct was unreasonable under the circumstances, particularly in light of the fact that simple and minimal measures, such as the application of salt or sand, would have eliminated or significantly reduced the hazard.
Halley v. Hugh Nawn, Inc., 356 Mass. 28.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on whether the plaintiff was contributorily negligent or assumed the risk in encountering an open trench, and on whether those issues should go to the jury. It does not discuss the reasonableness of the defendants’ conduct in terms of taking simple remedial safety measures like applying salt or sand, nor does it analyze minimal steps to reduce a hazard. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about unreasonable conduct for failing to use simple measures such as salt or sand.
Halley v. Hugh Nawn, Inc., 356 Mass. 28.relevant_excerpt: "At the time of the accident the trench was 'well lighted.' The weather 'was good and it was dry.' There were 'no horses, warning signals, barriers, or blinking lights in the area where she fell, or next to or around the trench or near the metal plate.' The placement of such barriers next to and around a trench was 'customary and usual.' ... The questions of contributory negligence and assumption of the risk were for the jury to determine."

Schwartz v. Com., 419 Mass. 306 (1995).proposition: Plaintiff was lawfully on the sidewalk for a business-related purpose at the time of the incident and had no reasonable notice of the danger posed by the icy pathway.
Schwartz v. Com., 419 Mass. 306 (1995).support_reasoning: The opinion deals solely with criminal sentencing, appellate procedure, and postconviction motions under Mass. R. Crim. P. 29(a) and 30(a). It does not discuss premises liability, plaintiffs, sidewalks, icy conditions, business purposes, or notice of danger. Therefore it cannot be authority for the proposition about a plaintiff’s lawful presence on a sidewalk and lack of notice of an icy pathway.
Schwartz v. Com., 419 Mass. 306 (1995).relevant_excerpt: These appeals arise from the sentencing of the defendant following his guilty plea to a charge of armed robbery in violation of G. L. c. 265, § 17 (1992 ed.), and to several other offenses.... The defendant was sentenced to from six to ten years at the Massachusetts Correctional Institution at Cedar Junction.... Motion pursuant to Mass. R. Crim. P. 29 (a). Rule 29 (a) requires that a defendant file his motion within sixty days after the imposition of the sentence.

Souza v. Walgreens East Inc., 84 Mass. A.raw_text: Souza v. Walgreens East Inc., 84 Mass. App. Ct. 381 (2013)
Souza v. Walgreens East Inc., 84 Mass. A.proposition: Plaintiff was lawfully on the sidewalk for a business-related purpose at the time of the incident and had no reasonable notice of the danger posed by the icy pathway.
Souza v. Walgreens East Inc., 84 Mass. A.support_reasoning: The opinion provided is not Souza v. Walgreens East Inc. and does not concern premises liability, sidewalk conditions, or icy pathways. It addresses criminal convictions for inducing minors to become prostitutes and deriving support from prostitution. Because the case does not deal with a plaintiff’s lawful presence on a sidewalk, business purpose, or notice of an icy condition, it cannot support the stated proposition.
Souza v. Walgreens East Inc., 84 Mass. A.relevant_excerpt: The case involved three minors, Gail, Beth, and Maureen (collectively, girls), ages sixteen to seventeen, who the Commonwealth maintained were persuaded to participate in a prostitution business operated by Halstrom with the assistance of Gorgoglione.

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner’s knowledge of a hazardous condition, combined with a failure to take reasonable actions to remedy that condition, constitutes actionable negligence.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly grounds Massachusetts premises liability in Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343, which imposes liability where a land possessor knows or should know of a dangerous condition and "fails to exercise reasonable care to protect" invitees. The court reiterates that liability traditionally attaches only when the owner has actual or constructive notice of a dangerous condition "sufficient to allow time for the owner to remedy the condition," and then refines the notice element via the mode-of-operation doctrine, but still requires proof that the owner failed to take reasonable precautions. This squarely matches the proposition that knowledge plus failure to take reasonable remedial action constitutes actionable negligence.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 (1965), states: “A possessor of land is subject to liability for physical harm caused to his invitees by a condition on the land if, but only if, he (a) knows or by the exercise of reasonable care would discover the condition, and should realize that it involves an unreasonable risk of harm to such invitees, … and (c) fails to exercise reasonable care to protect them against the danger.” … This court has thus held that premises liability attaches only if a store owner has actual or constructive notice of the existence of the dangerous condition, sufficient to allow time for the owner to remedy the condition.

Monsour v. Haney, 284 Mass. 267 (1933).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner’s knowledge of a hazardous condition, combined with a failure to take reasonable actions to remedy that condition, constitutes actionable negligence.
Monsour v. Haney, 284 Mass. 267 (1933).support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with procedural and pleading issues in a tort case involving workers’ compensation—specifically, whether an amended answer alleging compensation status should have been struck and the respective roles of judge and jury under G.L. c. 152, § 15. It does not address premises liability, hazardous property conditions, or standards for a property owner’s negligence in failing to remedy known hazards. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the stated negligence proposition under Massachusetts law.
Monsour v. Haney, 284 Mass. 267 (1933).relevant_excerpt: "The facts alleged would not be a defence to the action but would be ground, available by motion, for refusing to permit the employee to prosecute it... In this case, however, by the plaintiff’s consent, the immaterial allegations in the amendment became a part of the answer and it was not thereafter open to him, as matter of right, to contend that they were not properly a part thereof... For this reason the denial of the motion was not reversible error."
